node.contents: Looks more like the destination of System.err is full than a threading problem in the Java

astNode.text: Looks more like the destination of System.err is full than a threading problem in the Java

node.contents: @MarkoTopolnik You're right

astNode.text: @MarkoTopolnik You're right

node.contents: @MikeSamuel You may very well be on the right path there. I'm just going to update the question with those two elements: 1. I use log4j, so it is kind of dumb of me to also use System.err directly. 2. The processes calling the java program are slices of a Greenplum database during a `create external web table ... execute` (to load lots of data quickly). I'm not sure where System.err goes --it was really used to get some stats on the throughput speed during development.

astNode.text: @MikeSamuel You may very well be on the right path there. I'm just going to update the question with those two elements: 1. I use log4j, so it is kind of dumb of me to also use System.err directly. 2. The processes calling the java program are slices of a Greenplum database during a `create external web table ... execute` (to load lots of data quickly). I'm not sure where System.err goes --it was really used to get some stats on the throughput speed during development.

node.contents: So `System.err` and `System.out` are not your problem. The underlying `PrintStream` object is already synchronized. You don't need to do any locking around them at all.

astNode.text: So `System.err` and `System.out` are not your problem. The underlying `PrintStream` object is already synchronized. You don't need to do any locking around them at all.

node.contents: @JohnVint `System.err` is a `PrintStream`.

astNode.text: @JohnVint `System.err` is a `PrintStream`.

node.contents: 1. Is there any chance you're running an endless loop and `System.err` is not really blocking? The relevant code sample would help us eliminate such hypotheses in advance. 2. Is `System.err` by any chance redirected to a sink that can in fact block? May I point out that you don't have a case of a deadlock, but I/O blocking (your thread is RUNNABLE).

astNode.text: 1. Is there any chance you're running an endless loop and `System.err` is not really blocking? The relevant code sample would help us eliminate such hypotheses in advance. 2. Is `System.err` by any chance redirected to a sink that can in fact block? May I point out that you don't have a case of a deadlock, but I/O blocking (your thread is RUNNABLE).

node.contents: `System.err` and `System.out` often fill up a buffer which is drained by some other process, such as a console, or operating system as the content is streamed to a file. Have you redirected them to something that needs to be drained? Is that draining happening in this same process?

astNode.text: `System.err` and `System.out` often fill up a buffer which is drained by some other process, such as a console, or operating system as the content is streamed to a file. Have you redirected them to something that needs to be drained? Is that draining happening in this same process?

node.contents: @mikesamuel I think your answer is correct. If you enter it as answer and not as comment, I could accept it. Thanks!

astNode.text: @mikesamuel I think your answer is correct. If you enter it as answer and not as comment, I could accept it. Thanks!

node.contents: I'm a little baffled.

astNode.text: I'm a little baffled.

node.contents: I have two threads writing to System.err (and System.out), and eventually they get stuck in a thread lock. Are System.err and System.out really not thread-safe?

astNode.text: I have two threads writing to System.err (and System.out), and eventually they get stuck in a thread lock. Are System.err and System.out really not thread-safe?

node.contents: The structure of the program at that point is:

astNode.text: The structure of the program at that point is:

node.contents:
• main thread having launched two Reader threads to do some processing and printout, called via a ThreadPoolExecutor.
  • one Reader thread ("s3gp-2") that is blocked on System.err.format(), from within a separate IOStats object, in a synchronized method called IOStats.add().
  • another Reader thread that is (correctly) blocked trying to call the same IOStats.add() method that is blocked on System.err.format().

astNode.text:
• main thread having launched two Reader threads to do some processing and printout, called via a ThreadPoolExecutor.
  • one Reader thread ("s3gp-2") that is blocked on System.err.format(), from within a separate IOStats object, in a synchronized method called IOStats.add().
  • another Reader thread that is (correctly) blocked trying to call the same IOStats.add() method that is blocked on System.err.format().

node.contents: Note that each Reader typically writes to System.err and System.out.

astNode.text: Note that each Reader typically writes to System.err and System.out.

node.contents: Should I have a separate singleton object that handles all output with synchronized methods? Any insight very appreciated, as usual.

astNode.text: Should I have a separate singleton object that handles all output with synchronized methods? Any insight very appreciated, as usual.

node.contents: I realize that I should give a bit more context: that java program is invoked in parallel by all the n segments of a Greenplum DB (via a create external web table ... execute prgm). The locking behavior is extremely rare and usually all goes well. When the problem occurs, all the n processes are blocked. I am focusing on just one of them for the debugging.

astNode.text: I realize that I should give a bit more context: that java program is invoked in parallel by all the n segments of a Greenplum DB (via a create external web table ... execute prgm). The locking behavior is extremely rare and usually all goes well. When the problem occurs, all the n processes are blocked. I am focusing on just one of them for the debugging.

node.contents: Some more notes:

astNode.text: Some more notes:

node.contents:
1. For a few minutes, I thought that the fact that I also use log4j.Logger might cause trouble. But, in fact, there is no Console appender used for that program so I'm less inclined to think that is the problem.
  2. using lsof as well as ls -l /proc/$pid/fd, I observe that the stderr of the java process that is blocked in a pipe that is also read by postgres. As one commenter suggested, it might be that this pipe is not actually drained by postgres, and that blocks the System.err print out.

astNode.text:
1. For a few minutes, I thought that the fact that I also use log4j.Logger might cause trouble. But, in fact, there is no Console appender used for that program so I'm less inclined to think that is the problem.
  2. using lsof as well as ls -l /proc/$pid/fd, I observe that the stderr of the java process that is blocked in a pipe that is also read by postgres. As one commenter suggested, it might be that this pipe is not actually drained by postgres, and that blocks the System.err print out.

node.contents: In fact here are the relevant lines:

astNode.text: In fact here are the relevant lines:

elements.contents: % lsof | head -1 COMMAND PID USER FD TYPE DEVICE SIZE NODE NAME % lsof | grep $pid | grep ' 2w ' java 10047 gpadmin 2w FIFO 0,6 26854739 pipe % lsof | grep $pid | grep ' 2w ' java 10047 gpadmin 2w FIFO 0,6 26854739 pipe % node=26854739 % lsof | grep $node postgres 10028 gpadmin 26r FIFO 0,6 26854739 pipe sh 10046 gpadmin 2w FIFO 0,6 26854739 pipe java 10047 gpadmin 2w FIFO 0,6 26854739 pipe
